```{r library}
library(tidyverse)
library(stargazer)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(extrafont)
```
```{r message=FALSE}
faculty <- read_csv("Faculty.csv")
mf_grad <- read_csv("mfgrad.csv")
med_salary<-read_csv("salary.csv")
phd_field<-read_csv("phd_field.csv")

```

```{r}
enroll_graph <- ggplot(mf_grad) +
  geom_line(aes(color="Male", x=Year, y=`Total Male`)) +
  geom_line(aes(color="Female", x=Year, y = `Total Female`))

enroll_graph
```


```{r correlation coefficient}
# CLoser to 1, the better 
#Same as pearson's test
cor(mf_grad$Year, mf_grad$`Total Male`)
cor(mf_grad$Year, mf_grad$`Total Female`)

#Numbers suggest linear releation between year and # of students (both genders) 
```

```{r linear model for male}
m_grad_lm<-lm(formula = Year ~ `Total Male`, data = mf_grad)
summary(m_grad_lm)
```

```{r, pearson's R, echo = FALSE}

m_grad_pc<-cor.test(mf_grad$Year, mf_grad$`Total Male`)

```

```{r graph, fig.height = 4, fig.width = 6, echo = FALSE}

predicted <- predict(m_grad_lm, interval = "confidence", level = 0.95)
full_data <- data.frame(mf_grad, predicted)

ggplot(full_data, aes(x = Year, y = Total.Male)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_line(aes(x = Year, y = fit)) +
  geom_ribbon(aes(x = Year, ymin = lwr, ymax = upr), alpha = 0.3) +
  theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        panel.background = element_blank(), 
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"), 
        text = element_text(family = "Times New Roman")) +
  xlab("Year") +
  ylab("Students Enrolled") +
  annotate("text", 
           x = 4.5, 
           y = 4.3, 
           label = "y = 9.422e-05x - 1.902e+03", 
           family = "Times New Roman", 
           size = 5) +
  annotate("text", 
           x = 4.5, 
           y = 4.0, 
           label = "italic(R)^2 == 0.85", 
           parse = TRUE, 
           family = "Times New Roman", 
           size = 5)


```
\newline

**Figure 1. Relationship between *Setosa* iris sepal length (cm) and width (cm).** *Setosa* sepal length significantly predicts sepal width (*b* = 0.79, t(48) = 7.6, *p* < 0.001) with a strong positive correlation between the two (Pearson's *r* = 0.74). The overall model explains a significant amount of variance in sepal width (F(1,48) = 59, *p* < 0.001, $R^2$ = 0.55). Gray region is the 95% confidence interval for the mean predicted value.
